paper_title: Cu media constructed Z-scheme heterojunction of UiO-66-NH2/Cu2O/Cu for enhanced photocatalytic induction of CO2

catalyst.source: Cu media constructed Z-scheme heterojunction of UiO-66-NH2/Cu2O/Cu for enhanced photocatalytic induction of CO2
catalyst.context: Cu media constructed Z-scheme heterojunction of UiO-66-NH2/Cu2O/Cu for enhanced photocatalytic induction of CO2

catalyst.source: In this work, we report indirect Z-scheme heterojunction of UiO-66-NH 2 /Cu 2 O/Cu, which achieves highly CO 2 photocatalytic conversion to CO.
catalyst.context: Z-scheme heterojunction can effectively separate photo-generated carriers and enhance photocatalytic activity of CO 2 reduction.In this work, we report indirect Z-scheme heterojunction of UiO-66-NH 2 /Cu 2 O/Cu, which achieves highly CO 2 photocatalytic conversion to CO.Among these, UiO-66-NH 2 /Cu 2 O/Cu-0.39(U/C/Cu-0.39)displays the best activity with a CO yield of 4.54 molg -1 h -1 , which is 37.8 times higher than that for UiO-66-NH 2 and 50.4 times higher than that for Cu 2 O. Cu not only acts as the electron conductor of the indirect Z-scheme heterojunction to promote the charge carrier transmission, but also acts as the active site of CO 2 reduction.The increase of active sites and the CO 2 adsorption capacity results in the superior photocatalytic performances.

catalyst.source: The UiO-66-NH 2 /Cu 2 O/Cu-0.39gave evidence of excellent photocatalytic activity for conversion of CO 2 to CO, in which the yield of CO reached 4.54 molg -1 h -1 .
catalyst.context: In this report, UiO-66-NH 2 /Cu 2 O/Cu indirect Z-scheme heterojunction was prepared through the coupling UiO-66-NH 2 and Cu 2 O. Cu derived from Cu 2 O served as an electron mediator for the indirect Zscheme heterojunction.The UiO-66-NH 2 /Cu 2 O/Cu-0.39gave evidence of excellent photocatalytic activity for conversion of CO 2 to CO, in which the yield of CO reached 4.54 molg -1 h -1 .The key factors that led to the improved photocatalytic activity were the following: (1) Suitable band structures make it possible to construct Z-scheme heterojunction; (2) UiO-66-NH 2 slowed down the photo-corrosion rate of Cu 2 O and increased CO 2 adsorption capacity; (3) Cu accelerates the migration rate of charge carriers and provides active sites for CO 2 reduction. proportion of organic elements (C, H, N and O) were determined by the elemental Micro cube instrument and elemental EL III, respectively.The optical properties of the samples were characterized on UV-Vis spectrophotometer (UV-2450; Shimazu, Japan) in the range of 200-800 nm and BaSO 4 was used as a reference standard.Steady-state photoluminescence (PL) spectra and time-resolved PL decay curves were measured by photoluminescence detector (Edinburgh instruments FLS980).Electron-spin-resonance (ESR) tests were carried out on Bruker A300-10/12 Electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer.Transient photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy were conducted on Versa-STAT electrochemical workstation (Versa-STAT 3, Beijing, China).N 2 adsorption and CO 2 adsorption were measured on a TriStar II 3020 and ASAP 2460, respectively.Ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) was used to measure the work function () using He I emission (21.2 eV) as the source of ultra-violet light.The work function of the detector is 4.93 eV.The work function values of samples were obtained by formula (1): 21.2 -E -4.93 (E was energy distance from the upper onset to secondary onset). lamp.source: Photocatalytic CO 2 reductions tests were carried out at 20 C in a gasclosed quartz reactor, containing 50.0 mg photocatalyst and 100 mL H 2 O as the proton source under UV-vis irradiation (300 W Xe lamp) for 4 h.
lamp.context: The crystal structures of the samples were analyzed with a BRUKER D8 ADVANCE X-ray Diffractometer (XRD) with the scan range of 5-80 and the scan speed of 5 /min (Cu K radiation).X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to investigate the oxidation state of the photocatalyst by Thermo Fisher Scientific (Escalab 250Xi) equipped with a Mg K source (The binding energy of C1s was set at 284.8 eV as a reference).Scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) were performed on FEI Quanta FEG 250.Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and mapping was also employed for elemental analysis and their distribution which was attached to the SEM.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were analyzed on JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope at 200 kV.The amount of Cu and Zr were determined by an Agilent 720 inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-OES).The Cu 2 O were prepared according to a previously reported method 34.The preparation process of Cu 2 O were displayed in Scheme 1a.For the synthesis of Cu 2 O, 8 mL of CuSO 4 5H 2 O (0.68 M) and 7.2 g PVP was dissolved into 136 mL of deionized (DI) water.The mixture was stirred with a magnetic stirrer for 20 min, and then 8 mL of Na 3 C 6 H 5 O 7 2H 2 O (0.74 M) and 8 mL of Na 2 CO 3 (1.2M) was added in dropwise manner in sequence.After 10 min, 8 mL of C 6 H 12 O 6 (1.4 M) was slowly dropped into this solution.The solution was heated at 80 C for 2 h and then cooled to room temperature.The resulting reactant was aged for 7 days in air.The orange precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water and ethanol alternately several times.Finally, the product was vacuum dried at 60 C for 6 h. UiO-66-NH 2 were synthesized according to the literature with a little modification 35.0.0467 g ZrCl 4 and 0.0363 g ATA were added to 20.42 mL of DMA to obtain solution A. Then, 7.8 mL of acetic acid was Scheme 1.The preparation process of Cu 2 O and U/C/Cu.added to solution A and stirred for 1 h room temperature.Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 C for 12 h.The white product was obtained by centrifugation, washed with DMF and methanol and dried under vacuum at 80 C for h. The preparation process of U/C/Cu were displayed in Scheme 1b.0.2 g Cu 2 O and 0.0467 g ZrCl 4 were added to 20.42 mL of DMA and stirred for 30 min to obtain solution A. After that, 0.0363 g ATA was added to solution A, followed by an ultrasonic treatment for 10 min.Then, 7.8 mL of acetic acid was added to solution A. The mixture was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 C for h.Finally, the pink product, namely U/C/Cu-0.23,was obtained by centrifugation, washed with DMF and methanol and dried under vacuum at 80 C for 6 h.The addition amount of the composite photocatalyst raw material is shown in Table 1.In addition, we have prepared U/C-0.39, that was, no acetic acid was added during the synthesis process. Photocatalytic CO 2 reductions tests were carried out at 20 C in a gasclosed quartz reactor, containing 50.0 mg photocatalyst and 100 mL H 2 O as the proton source under UV-vis irradiation (300 W Xe lamp) for 4 h.The reaction system was stirred with a magnetic stirrer and bubbled with high-purity CO 2 (99.999) in the dark at least 20 min before light illumination.In the process of photocatalytic reaction, gas product of the CO 2 photo reduction was detected by gas chromatograph (GC5890, FID detector with reformer, Nanjing Kejie instrument) every hour.The temperatures for FID, an injection and oven temperature were 200, and 60 C, respectively, and retention time of CO is 1.2 min.The 13 isotopic labelling was confirmed using the gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (Agilent, 7890B-5977B). The experimental details were described in supporting information file.
